entry.title: Semantic Parsing
entry.content:
Title

ã€ŠHow Far are We from Effective Context Modeling? An Exploratory Study on Semantic Parsing in Contextã€‹

Abstract

Recently semantic parsing in context has received considerable attention, which is challenging since there are complex contextual phenomena. Previous works verifified their proposed methods in limited scenarios, which motivates us to conduct an exploratory study on context modeling methods under real-world semantic parsing in context. We present a grammar-based decoding semantic parser and adapt typical context modeling methods on top of it. We evaluate 13 context modeling methods on two large complex cross-domain datasets, and our best model achieves state-of-the-art performances on both datasets with signifificant improvements.Furthermore, we summarize the most frequent contextual phenomena, with a fifine-grained analysis on representative models, which may shed light on potential research directions. Our code is available at https://github.com/microsoft/ContextualSP.

entry.title: compositional Generalization
entry.content:
Title

ã€ŠCompositional Generalization by Learning Analytical Expressionsã€‹

Abstract

Compositional generalization is a basic and essential intellective capability of human beings, which allows us to recombine known parts readily. However,existing neural network based models have been proven to be extremely defificient in such a capability. Inspired by work in cognition which argues compositionality can be captured by variable slots with symbolic functions, we present a refreshing view that connects a memory-augmented neural model with analytical expressions, to achieve compositional generalization. Our model consists of two cooperative neural modules, Composer and Solver, fifitting well with the cognitive argument while being able to be trained in an end-to-end manner via a hierarchical reinforcement learning algorithm. Experiments on the well-known benchmark SCAN demonstrate that our model seizes a great ability of compositional generalization, solving all challenges addressed by previous works with 100% accuracies.

entry.title: QA_KA
entry.content:
Title

ã€ŠScalable Multi-Hop Relational Reasoning for Knowledge-Aware Question Answeringã€‹

Abstract

Existing work on augmenting question answering (QA) models with external knowledge (e.g., knowledge graphs) either struggle to model multi-hop relations effificiently,or lack transparency into the modelâ€™s prediction rationale. In this paper, we propose a novel knowledge-aware approach that equips pre-trained language models (PTLMs) with a multi-hop relational reasoning module, named multi-hop graph relation network (MHGRN).It performs multi-hop, multi-relational reasoning over subgraphs extracted from external knowledge graphs. The proposed reasoning module unififies path-based reasoning methods and graph neural networks to achieve better interpretability and scalability. We also empirically show its effectiveness and scalability on CommonsenseQA and OpenbookQA datasets,and interpret its behaviors with case studies1.

ç°åœ¨ä½¿ç”¨å¤–éƒ¨çŸ¥è¯†å¢å¼ºQAçš„æ¨¡å‹åŠªåŠ›åœ¨å¯¹å¤šè·³å…³ç³»è¿›è¡Œå»ºæ¨¡ï¼Œæˆ–è€…ç¼ºä¹å¯¹æ¨¡å‹é¢„æµ‹çš„é€æ˜åº¦ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬æå‡ºä¸€ç§æœ‰é¢„è®­ç»ƒè¯­è¨€æ¨¡å‹çš„çŸ¥è¯†æ„ŸçŸ¥æ–¹æ³•ã€‚å®ç°äº†ä»å¤–éƒ¨çŸ¥è¯†å›¾è°±æå–çš„å­å›¾ä¸Šè¿›è¡Œå¤šè·³ï¼Œå¤šå…³ç³»çš„æ¨ç†ã€‚å°†åŸºäºè·¯å¾„çš„æ¨ç†æ–¹æ³•å’Œå›¾ç¥ç»ç½‘ç»œç»“åˆèµ·æ¥å®ç°äº†æ›´å¥½çš„å¯è§£é‡Šæ€§ï¼Œå¯æ‰©å±•æ€§ã€‚

3 Background: Multi-Relational Graph Encoding Methods

å¯¹å¤šå…³ç³»å›¾è°±çš„ç¼–ç æ–¹æ³•æœ‰ä¸¤ç§ç­–ç•¥ï¼šGNN,path-based models.GNNé€šè¿‡åœ¨èŠ‚ç‚¹ä¹‹é—´ä¼ é€’ä¿¡æ¯æ¥ç»“æ„åŒ–ä¿¡æ¯ï¼Œé¦–å…ˆå°†å›¾åˆ†è§£åˆ†è§£æˆpathsï¼Œå†åœ¨pathsä¸ŠåŠ å…¥ç‰¹å¾ã€‚

Graph Encoding with GNNs

å°†èŠ‚ç‚¹ç‰¹å¾ä½œä¸ºè¾“å…¥ï¼Œé€šè¿‡ä¿¡æ¯ä¼ é€’è®¡ç®—ä»–ä»¬çš„ç›¸å…³èŠ‚ç‚¹embeddingï¼Œç„¶åé€šè¿‡æ± åŒ–èŠ‚ç‚¹embeddingè·å¾—ç´§å‡‘å›¾å½¢è¡¨ç¤ºã€‚

GNNçš„å˜ä½“ï¼š

  2. é€šè¿‡å¯¹æ¯ä¸€ä¸ªè¾¹ç±»å‹å®šä¹‰æŒ‡å®šå…³ç³»çš„æƒé‡çŸ©é˜µæ¥ç¼–ç å¤šå…³ç³»å›¾è°±ã€‚

ä½†æ˜¯GNNåªå®ç°äº†node-levelçš„å¯ä¼¸ç¼©æ€§ï¼Œåœ¨è·¯å¾„çº§åˆ«

Graph Encoding with Path-Based Models

é™¤äº†ç”¨GNNå¯¹å›¾è¿›è¡Œå»ºæ¨¡ï¼Œå°†å›¾è§†ä¸ºè¿æ¥å®ä½“å¯¹çš„å…³ç³»è·¯å¾„é›†åˆã€‚RNsï¼ˆRelationship Networksï¼‰å¯ä»¥é€‚ç”¨äºQAè®¾ç½®ä¸‹çš„å¤šå…³ç³»å›¾å‹ç¼–ç ã€‚RNä½¿ç”¨MLPså¯¹Gä¸­çš„ä¸‰å…ƒç»„(One-hop pathsï¼Œé—®é¢˜æŒ‡å‘é€‰é¡¹)è¿›è¡Œç¼–ç ï¼Œ

entry.title: LXMERT
entry.content:
Title

LXMERT: Learning Cross-Modality Encoder Representations from Transformers

Abstract

Vision-and-language reasoning requires an understanding of visual concepts, language semantics, and, most importantly, the alignment and relationships between these two modalities. We thus propose the LXMERT (Learning Cross-Modality Encoder Representations from Transformers) framework to learn these vision-and-language connections.

good result on two dataset:VQA,GQA

entry.title: GPT
entry.content:
Title

Improving Language Understanding by Generative Pre-Training

Abstract

Natural language understanding comprises a wide range of diverse tasks such as textual entailment, question answering, semantic similarity assessment, and document classifification.Although large unlabeled text corpora are abundant, labeled data for learning these specifific tasks is scarce, making it challenging for discriminatively trained models to perform adequately. We demonstrate that large gains on these tasks can be realized by generative pre-training of a language model on a diverse corpus of unlabeled text, followed by discriminative fifine-tuning on each specifific task.

We introduced a framework for achieving strong natural language understanding with a single task-agnostic model through generative pre-training and discriminative fifine-tuning.

è§£å†³çš„é—®é¢˜ï¼šç”¨æ¥å­¦ä¹ specific taskçš„labled dataæ˜¯ç¨€ç¼ºçš„ã€‚è®©é’ˆå¯¹æ€§çš„æ¨¡å‹å……åˆ†æ‰§è¡Œå…·æœ‰æŒ‘æˆ˜æ€§ã€‚

è§£å†³æ–¹æ³•ï¼šgenerative pre-training,discriminative fifine-tuning(task-aware input transformations)

ç»“æœï¼šimproveï¼š8.9%-CRã€‚5.7%-QA,1.5%-TE

Introduction

çº¢æ¡†æ ‡æ³¨å‡ºäº†Transformeræ¨¡å‹çš„ä½ç½®,tokençº§çš„è¾“å…¥ä¸Linearå±‚ä¹‹é—´.tokençº§çš„è¾“å…¥æ˜¯åˆ›æ–°ç‚¹,å®ƒå®ç°äº†æ›´ç»†ç²’åº¦çš„fine-tunning(å¾®è°ƒ).å…ˆä½¿ç”¨æœªæ ‡è®°çš„æ•°æ®å­¦ä¹ æ¨¡å‹çš„åˆå§‹å‚æ•°,ç„¶åå†ç›‘ç£ç›®æ ‡ä¸‹å°†è¿™äº›å‚æ•°é€‚åº”äºç‰¹å®šçš„ç›®æ ‡.ç›®æ ‡ä»»åŠ¡ä¸æœªæ ‡è®°æ•°æ®é›†ä¸éœ€è¦åœ¨åŒä¸€åŒºåŸŸ,è·¨ä»»åŠ¡çš„æ¨¡å‹è¡¨ç°éƒ½å¾ˆå¥½.

Conclusion

Title

ã€ŠEvent2Mind: Commonsense Inference on Events, Intents, and Reactionsã€‹

Abstract

We investigate a new commonsense inference task: given an event described in a short free-form text (â€œX drinks coffee in the morningâ€), a system reasons about the likely intents (â€œX wants to stay awakeâ€) and reactions (â€œX feels alertâ€) of the eventâ€™s participants.

entry.title: SpanBert
entry.content:
Title

ã€ŠSpanBERT: Improving Pre-training by Representing and Predicting Spansã€‹

Abstract

â€‹ We present SpanBERT, a pre-training method that is designed to better represent and predict spans of text. Our approach extends BERT by (1) masking contiguous random spans, rather than random tokens, and (2) training the span boundary representations to predict the entire content of the masked span, without relying on the individual token representations within it. SpanBERT consistently outperforms BERT and our better-tuned baselines, with substantial gains on span selection tasks such as question answering and coreference resolution.

â€‹ SpanBertç›¸æ¯”äºBertæ›´å¤Ÿæ›´å¥½çš„è¡¨ç¤ºå’Œé¢„æµ‹æ–‡ç« çš„èŒƒå›´ã€‚

entry.title: BERT
entry.content:
Title

ã€Š**BERT: Pre-training of Deep Bidirectional Transformers for Language Understanding**ã€‹

1.Abstract

â€‹ We introduce a new language representation model called BERT, which stands for Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers. Unlike recent language representation models (Peters et al., 2018a; Radford et al., 2018), BERT is designed to pretrain deep bidirectional representations from unlabeled text by jointly conditioning on both left and right context in all layers. As a result, the pre-trained BERT model can be fifinetuned with just one additional output layer to create state-of-the-art models for a wide range of tasks, such as question answering and language inference, without substantial task specifific architecture modififications.

â€‹ BERTå…¨ç§°Bidirectional Encoder Representation from Transformer,å®ƒæ˜¯ä¸€ç§åœ¨æœªæ ‡è®°çš„æ–‡æœ¬ä¸­,ç”¨æ‰€æœ‰layerä¸Šä¸‹æ–‡ä¸ºå…±åŒæ¡ä»¶è¿›è¡Œæ·±åº¦åŒå‘çš„é¢„è®­ç»ƒè¡¨ç¤ºã€‚é¢„è®­ç»ƒBERTæ¨¡å‹åªå¾®è°ƒä¸€ä¸ªé¢å¤–è¾“å‡ºå±‚ï¼Œæ²¡æœ‰è¿›è¡Œå®è´¨æ€§ä»»åŠ¡ç‰¹å®šçš„æ¨¡å‹ä¿®æ”¹ï¼Œä¸ºå¤šé¢†åŸŸï¼ˆæ¯”å¦‚é—®é¢˜å›ç­”å’Œè¯­è¨€æ¨ç†ï¼‰çš„ä»»åŠ¡åˆ›é€ ä¸€ä¸ªå…ˆè¿›çš„æ¨¡å‹ã€‚

2.Introduction

â€‹ é¢„è®­ç»ƒæ¨¡å‹åœ¨è®¸å¤šä»»åŠ¡ä¸­è¡¨ç°å¾ˆå¥½ï¼Œsuch asï¼š

Aï¼šsentence-levelï¼ˆæ¨ç†å’Œè§£é‡Šinferenceå’Œparaphrasing)

B: token-level (NER,QA)

â€‹ é¢„è®­ç»ƒçš„ä¸¤ä¸ªä¸‹æ¸¸ä»»åŠ¡ï¼šåŸºäºç‰¹å¾(ELMO)ä»¥åŠå¾®è°ƒ(OpenAI GPT)å‚æ•°

â€‹ fine-tunningå¾®è°ƒåœ¨Transformerçš„è‡ªæ³¨æ„åŠ›å±‚ä¸­åªèƒ½å…³æ³¨å‰åºtokençš„ä¿¡æ¯ï¼Œåœ¨QAè¿™ç§éœ€è¦å…³æ³¨ä¸Šä¸‹æ–‡çš„åº”ç”¨ä¸­å­˜åœ¨é—®é¢˜ã€‚è¿˜æå‡ºäº†masked language model(MLM),å®ƒé€šè¿‡éšæœºmaskä¸€äº›è¾“å…¥ä¸­çš„tokenæ¥éšæœºé¢„æµ‹ä¸€äº›åŸºäºæ–‡æœ¬èƒŒæ™¯çš„masked token

3.BERT

  • Bertæ¨¡å‹çš„æ¡†æ¶åŒ…æ‹¬ä¸¤ä¸ªéƒ¨åˆ†ï¼špre-training,fine-tunning:
    pre-training - unlabeled data - pre-traning task

    B:fine-tunning - labeled data - downstream task

  • Model architecture:multi-layer bidirectional Transformer

    num of layer:L,hidden size:H,self-attention head A

  • Input/Output Representation

[^Segment Embeddingæ˜¯æ ‡è®°tokenå±äºå¥å­Aè¿˜æ˜¯å¥å­Bçš„]:

entry.title: Code-allenlp
entry.content:
yield

text classification

Defining input and output

AllenNLP

one exampleï¼šone instance:one or more Fields(each Field is a input or output data) TextField(in) or LabelField(out)

Field->tensor to model

Read data

trasfer raw data to instances that match input/output spec

Make datasetReader

é€è¡Œè¯»å–textï¼Œå°†æ¯ä¸ªlineåˆ†æˆå•ä¸ªçš„tokenï¼Œåœ¨æ ¹æ®è¯æ±‡è¡¨ä¸­å¯¹åº”çš„idç»„æˆtensor

Build model

  • get features from each input word

  • combine word-level features to document-level feature vector

  • classify vector into one label

    Steps

[^batch_size:æ¯æ¬¡è®­ç»ƒæ—¶çš„æ ·æœ¬æ•°]:

  1. å¯¹inatancesè¿›è¡Œç¼–ç ç”ŸæˆToken IDsï¼ˆSingleIDTokenIndexr())
  2. å°†tokené€šè¿‡embeddingå‡½æ•°ï¼Œç”Ÿæˆvector
  3. å¯¹vectorè¿›è¡Œå‹ç¼©ï¼Œå˜æˆå•ä¸ªå‘é‡
  4. ç”Ÿæˆlabelæ¦‚ç‡åˆ†å¸ƒï¼Œå¯¹lossè¿›è¡Œè®¡ç®—

Allenlp structure

  1. is a Pytorch Model
  2. forward() makes output be a dictionary
  3. output includes loss key to optimize the model

æ€»æµç¨‹

Text -> classifier -> Instances(TextField+LabelField) -> Model(Embedding Vector+Seq2Vec Encoding) -> lables

Text->Text->instance->TokenIds(vector)->tensor->vector

Training and prediction

è¯»å–ç”µå½±æ•°æ®é›†

class ClassificationTsvReader(DatasetReader):    def __init__(self,                 lazy: bool = False,                 tokenizer: Tokenizer = None,                 token_indexers: Dict[str, TokenIndexer] = None,                 max_tokens: int = None):        super().__init__(lazy)        self.tokenizer = tokenizer or WhitespaceTokenizer()        self.token_indexers = token_indexers or {'tokens': SingleIdTokenIndexer()}        self.max_tokens = max_tokens    def _read(self, file_path: str) -> Iterable[Instance]:        with open(file_path, 'r') as lines:            for line in lines:                text, sentiment = line.strip().split('\t')                tokens = self.tokenizer.tokenize(text)                if self.max_tokens:                    tokens = tokens[:self.max_tokens]                text_field = TextField(tokens, self.token_indexers)                label_field = LabelField(sentiment)                fields = {'text': text_field, 'label': label_field}                yield Instance(fields)dataset_reader = ClassificationTsvReader(max_tokens=64)instances = dataset_reader.read("quick_start/data/movie_review/train.tsv")for instance in instances[:10]:    print(instance)

Text->Instancesï¼Œè¾“å‡ºæ˜¯ä»æ•°æ®é›†ä¸­è¯»å–çš„å‰åä¸ªinstance

Feeding instances to the model

class SimpleClassifier(Model):    def __init__(self,                 vocab: Vocabulary,                 embedder: TextFieldEmbedder,                 encoder: Seq2VecEncoder):        super().__init__(vocab)        self.embedder = embedder        self.encoder = encoder        num_labels = vocab.get_vocab_size("labels")        self.classifier = torch.nn.Linear(encoder.get_output_dim(), num_labels)    def forward(self,                text: Dict[str, torch.Tensor],                label: torch.Tensor) -> Dict[str, torch.Tensor]:        # Shape: (batch_size, num_tokens, embedding_dim)        embedded_text = self.embedder(text)        # Shape: (batch_size, num_tokens)        mask = util.get_text_field_mask(text)        # Shape: (batch_size, encoding_dim)        encoded_text = self.encoder(embedded_text, mask)        # Shape: (batch_size, num_labels)        logits = self.classifier(encoded_text)        # Shape: (batch_size, num_labels)        probs = torch.nn.functional.softmax(logits, dim=-1)        # Shape: (1,)        loss = torch.nn.functional.cross_entropy(logits, label)        return {'loss': loss, 'probs': probs}def run_training_loop():    dataset_reader = ClassificationTsvReader(max_tokens=64)    print("Reading data")    instances = dataset_reader.read("quick_start/data/movie_review/train.tsv")    vocab = build_vocab(instances)    model = build_model(vocab)    outputs = model.forward_on_instances(instances[:4])    print(outputs)def build_vocab(instances: Iterable[Instance]) -> Vocabulary:    print("Building the vocabulary")    return Vocabulary.from_instances(instances)def build_model(vocab: Vocabulary) -> Model:    print("Building the model")    vocab_size = vocab.get_vocab_size("tokens")    embedder = BasicTextFieldEmbedder(        {"tokens": Embedding(embedding_dim=10, num_embeddings=vocab_size)})    encoder = BagOfEmbeddingsEncoder(embedding_dim=10)    return SimpleClassifier(vocab, embedder, encoder)run_training_loop()

self.classifier = torch.nn.Linear(encoder.get_output_dim(), num_labels)

[^LInear(input_dim,output_dim):è¾“å…¥å‘é‡ç»´åº¦ï¼ˆbatch_size,input_dim),è¾“å‡ºå‘é‡ç»´åº¦ï¼ˆbatch_size,output_dim)]:

torch.nn.functional.cross_entropy

nll_losså‡½æ•°

è¿è¡Œç»“æœï¼š

[^ï¼Ÿï¼Ÿï¼Ÿembeddingï¼Œencodingè¿”å›çš„å°æ•°è®¡ç®—]:

entry.title: CCG-Supertagging-RNN
entry.content:
Title

ã€ŠCCG Supertagging with a Recurrent Neural Networkã€‹

Abstract

Recent work on supertagging using a feed-forward neural network achieved signifificant improvements for

CCG supertagging and parsing (Lewis and Steedman, 2014).However, their architecture is limited to

considering local contexts and does not naturally model sequences of arbitrary length.

Introduction

And third, in order to reduce computational requirements and feature sparsity, each tagging decision is made without considering any potentially useful contextual information beyond a local context window.

Q:

Above all,these sequences tell us the problem:the architecture canâ€™t consider local contect text and naturally model sequences of arbitrary.

[^rely too much on POS tagging,there three drawbacks]: POS taggingæ˜¯è¯­ä¹‰æ ‡ç­¾ï¼ŒNLTKè¯æ€§æ ‡æ³¨å™¨ï¼Œå…ˆå°†å¥å­ä¸­çš„æ‰€æœ‰wordåˆ†å¼€ï¼Œå†å¯¹æ¯ä¸€ä¸ªwordè¿›è¡Œè¯æ€§çš„æ ‡æ³¨ï¼Œç”Ÿæˆä¸€ä¸ªè¯­ä¹‰è¯æ±‡å¯¹ç…§åºåˆ—

1.the effectiveness of supertagging make the accuracy of out of-domain-data down

2.performance degradation will happen if there are rare or unseen words(features mainly base on raw words and POS tag)

3.the architecture canâ€™t consider local contect text

S:

RNN ï¼ŒDistributed word representation,C&C parser as supertagger

[^Word2vec:Distributed word representation,ä¸€ç§wordçš„ä½ç»´è¡¨ç¤ºï¼Œç›¸æ¯”äºone-hotï¼Œä»–çš„é€Ÿåº¦æ›´å¿«è€Œä¸”åŒ…å«è¯­ä¹‰ä¿¡æ¯ï¼Œå³è¯­ä¹‰ç›¸è¿‘çš„ä¸¤ä¸ªè¯è¯­è¡¨ç¤ºçš„å‘é‡ä¹‹é—´çš„è·ç¦»ä¹Ÿè¿‘]:

C:

we obtain substantial accuracy improvements, outperforming the feed-forward setup on both supertagging and parsing.

Reference

https://blog.csdn.net/wangyangjingjing/article/details/86631058

https://blog.csdn.net/AMDS123/article/details/67644298?utm_medium=distribute.pc_relevant_t0.none-task-blog-BlogCommendFromMachineLearnPai2-1.channel_param&depth_1-utm_source=distribute.pc_relevant_t0.none-task-blog-BlogCommendFromMachineLearnPai2-1.channel_param

entry.title: CCG-Supertagging-LSTM
entry.content:
Title

ã€ŠSupertagging with LSTMsã€‹

LSTMæ¡†æ¶

[^LSTMä¸­æœ‰ä¸‰ä¸ªé—¨ç”µè·¯è¿›è¡Œæ§åˆ¶ï¼Œé—¨ç”µè·¯è¾“å‡ºä¸º1æ—¶é—¨ç”µè·¯æ‰“å¼€ï¼Œåä¹‹å…³é—­ã€‚]: ç›¸æ¯”äºNerual Network,LSTMç›¸å½“äºå¤–æ¥å››ä¸ªç”µè·¯è¿›è¡Œè¾“å…¥ï¼Œæ¯æ¬¡è¾“å…¥éƒ½å¯¹ä¸¤ä¸ªè¾“å…¥è¿›è¡Œæƒå€¼çš„åŠ æƒè¿ç®—ã€‚æœ€åå¾—å‡ºoutput

Abstract

â€‹ In this paper we present new state-of-the-art performance on CCG supertagging and parsing.We analyze the performance of several neural models and demonstrate that while feed-forward architectures can compete with bidirectional LSTMs on POS tagging, models that encode the complete sentence are necessary for the long range syntactic information encoded in supertags.

entry.title: SpecAugment-Data Augmentation-ASR
entry.content:
Title

ã€ŠSpecAugment: A Simple Data Augmentation Methodfor Automatic Speech Recognitionã€‹

Abstract

We present SpecAugment, a simple data augmentation method for speech recognition. SpecAugment is applied directly to the feature inputs of a neural network (i.e., fifilter bank coef-fificients). The augmentation policy consists of warping the features, masking blocks of frequency channels, and masking blocks of time steps. We apply SpecAugment on Listen, Attend and Spell networks for end-to-end speech recognition tasks.

Reference

https://blog.csdn.net/u010801994/article/details/81914716

entry.title: End2EndASR-SL2SSL
entry.content:
Source

https://arxiv.org/abs/1911.08460

title

ã€ŠEND-TO-END ASR: FROM SUPERVISED TO SEMI-SUPERVISED

LEARNING WITH MODERN ARCHITECTURESã€‹

Abstract

We study pseudo-labeling for the semi-supervised training of ResNet, Time-Depth Separable ConvNets, and Transformers for speech recognition, with either CTC or Seq2Seq loss functions.

entry.title: Convs2s-MT
entry.content:
Title

ã€ŠConvolutional Sequence to Sequence Learningã€‹

Abstract

We introduce an architecture based entirely on convolutional neural networks.Compared to recurrent models, computations over all elements can be fully parallelized during training to better exploit the GPU hardware and optimization is easier since the number of non-linearities is fifixed and independent of the input length. Our use of gated linear units eases gradient propagation and we equip each decoder layer with a separate attention module.

Compared with RNN,CNNçš„è®¡ç®—å¹¶è¡Œæ€§æ›´å¥½ï¼Œè®­ç»ƒçš„æ—¶å€™å¯ä»¥æ›´å¥½åˆ©ç”¨GPUè€Œä¸”ä¼˜åŒ–æ›´å®¹æ˜“è¿›è¡Œï¼Œå› ä¸ºéçº¿æ€§å‚æ•°çš„æ•°é‡å›ºå®šï¼Œä¸è¾“å…¥é•¿åº¦æ— å…³ã€‚æˆ‘ä»¬ä½¿ç”¨é—¨æ§çº¿æ€§å•å…ƒæ¶ˆé™¤æ¢¯åº¦ä¼ æ’­

Compared with RNN,CNN create representation for fixed size,but the context size of the network can be easily made larger by stacking.CNNs do not depend on the previous time step and allow parallelization over every element in a seq.

[^RNN matain a hidden state of the entire past that prevents parallel computation]:

Muti-layer CNN create hierarchical representations over the input.

nearby elements interact at lower layer,distant one at higher.

Compared with RNN,this structure provides a shorter path to capture long-range dependenceies.

æˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥åœ¨çª—å£å¤§å°ä¸ºné€šè¿‡æ•æ‰å…³ç³»æ¥è·å¾—ç‰¹å¾è¡¨è¾¾ï¼ŒCNNçš„O(n/k),kä¸ºkernelâ€™s width,O(n) for RNN

Qï¼š

Bradbury et al. (2016) introduce recurrent pooling between a succession of convolutional layers,but doesnâ€™t improve result.

Gated CNN restricted the sixe of dataset and must be uesed with count-based model.

*partially CNN *shows well,but decoder is still recurrent.

S:

an architecture for seq2seq which is entirely convolutional.

included gated linear units,residual connection,attetion in decoder layer(control overhead)

C:

CNNæ¨¡å‹ç›¸æ¯”äºRNNåœ¨æ›´å¤§æ•°æ®é›†ä¸Šæå‡äº†ä¸€ä¸ªæ•°é‡çº§çš„é€Ÿåº¦ï¼Œç›¸æ¯”äºRNNæ›´èƒ½å‘ç°ç»„åˆç»“æ„ï¼Œä¾èµ–äºé—¨æ§ä»¥åŠmulti-attention

[^ç³»ç»ŸæŸä¸€æ—¶åˆ»çš„è¾“å‡ºæ˜¯ç”±å¤šä¸ªè¾“å…¥å…±åŒä½œç”¨çš„ç»“æœ]:

[^è®¡ç®—ç¬¬äºŒä¸ªå…ƒç´ åªéœ€å°†è“è‰²æ–¹æ¡†å‘å³ç§»åŠ¨ä¸€åˆ—]:

[^ä¸Šå›¾ä¸­é—´çš„å·ç§¯çŸ©é˜µé€šè¿‡å·ç§¯è¿ç®—å¯ä»¥çœ‹å‡ºè¾“å…¥çŸ©é˜µæ˜¯ä»æš—å˜äº®è¿˜æ˜¯ä»äº®å˜æš—]:

[^å·ç§¯çŸ©é˜µå¯ä»¥ç”¨æ¥å½“ä½œæ°´å¹³æˆ–å‚ç›´è¾¹ç¼˜æ£€æµ‹]:

[^ä¸­é—´ä¸€è¡Œçš„å‚æ•°æƒé‡å˜å¤§æ˜¯ä¸ºäº†å¢å¤§é²æ£’æ€§]:

å¯ä»¥å°†çŸ©é˜µçš„ä¹ä¸ªå‚æ•°å…¨éƒ½é€šè¿‡ç¥ç»ç½‘ç»œå»å­¦ä¹ ï¼ˆåå‘ç®—æ³•ï¼‰ï¼ŒçŸ©é˜µè¿˜å¯ä»¥è¿›è¡Œç¿»è½¬

å·ç§¯æ ¸ä¸Šæ‰€æœ‰ä½œç”¨ç‚¹ä¾æ¬¡ä½œç”¨äºåŸå§‹åƒç´ ç‚¹åï¼ˆå³ä¹˜èµ·æ¥ï¼‰ï¼Œçº¿æ€§å åŠ çš„è¾“å‡ºç»“æœï¼Œå³æ˜¯æœ€ç»ˆå·ç§¯çš„è¾“å‡ºï¼Œä¹Ÿæ˜¯æˆ‘ä»¬æƒ³è¦çš„ç»“æœï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬ç§°ä¸ºdestination pixel.

Padding

å¯¹è¾“å…¥çŸ©é˜µè¿›è¡Œå·ç§¯çš„æ—¶å€™ï¼Œå‡è®¾è¾“å…¥çŸ©é˜µç»´æ•°ä¸ºnï¼Œå·ç§¯çŸ©é˜µä¸ºfï¼Œåˆ™è¾“å‡ºçŸ©é˜µä¸ºn-f+1ï¼Œf>=1ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥è¾“å‡ºä¼šè¢«ç¼©å°ï¼Œè¿™æ ·è¾¹ç¼˜çš„ç‰¹å¾ä¼šä¸¢å¤±ã€‚

å¼•å…¥paddingï¼Œå¯¹è¾“å…¥çŸ©é˜µå››å‘¨è¿›è¡Œæ‰©å……ï¼Œå…ƒç´ ä¸º0.

æ ¹æ®æ˜¯å¦paddingï¼Œå°†å·ç§¯åˆ†ä¸ºValid,Sameã€‚

  • Vaildè¾“å‡ºçŸ©é˜µç»´æ•°ä¸ºn-f+1.
  • Sameè¾“å‡ºçŸ©é˜µn+2p-f+1(pä¸ºpaddingçš„ç»´æ•°)

è¾“å‡ºçŸ©é˜µçš„é€šé“æ•°å¯ä»¥éšç€æ ¸çš„æ•°é‡ç»§ç»­å¢åŠ 

Pooling layer

  • Max Pooling

    å¦‚æœåœ¨è¿‡æ»¤å™¨ä¸­æå–å‡ºä»»ä½•çš„ç‰¹å¾åˆ™ä¿ç•™æœ€å¤§å€¼ï¼Œåä¹‹åˆ™ä¸æ˜¯æœ€å¤§å€¼

  • Average pooling

    é€šè¿‡è®¡ç®—æ–¹å—ç‰¹å¾å€¼ä¸­çš„å¹³å‡æ•°æ¥è¿›è¡Œç‰¹å¾æå–ã€‚æ•ˆæœæ²¡æœ‰Max poolingå¥½ã€‚

    POOLå±‚æ— å‚æ•°ï¼Œå·ç§¯å±‚å‚æ•°è¾ƒå°‘ï¼Œå…¨è¿æ¥å±‚å‚æ•°æœ€å¤šï¼Œéšç€å±‚æ•°å¢åŠ ï¼Œæ¿€æ´»å€¼å‡å°‘ã€‚

    Why use CNN?

    é€šè¿‡å…±äº«å‚æ•°å’Œä½¿ç”¨ç¨€ç–ç½‘ç»œ(é˜²æ­¢è¿‡æ‹Ÿåˆ)æ¥å‡å°‘å‚æ•°ã€‚

    ç»å…¸ç½‘ç»œ

    LetNet-5

    [^æ—©æœŸpoolingåªæœ‰avgï¼Œäººä»¬æ—©æœŸä½¿ç”¨Sigmoid/tanh,è€ŒéRelu]:

    AlexNet

    æ®‹å·®ç½‘ç»œï¼ˆResidual block)

    ç¥ç»ç½‘ç»œçš„å±‚æ•°å¤ªæ·±ä¼šå¯¼è‡´æ¢¯åº¦çˆ†ç‚¸æˆ–æ¢¯åº¦æ¶ˆå¤±ã€‚æ®‹å·®ç½‘ç»œï¼Œå¯ä»¥å°†ä»ä¸€å±‚è·å–çš„æ¿€æ´»å€¼è¿…é€Ÿåé¦ˆç»™å…¶ä»–å±‚æˆ–æ˜¯æ›´æ·±çš„ç½‘ç»œã€‚

entry.title: dynamaticonv
entry.content:
Title

ã€ŠPay Less Attention With Lightweight and Dynamic Convolutions](https://arxiv.org/abs/1901.10430)ã€‹

Abstract

self-attentionåœ¨current time stepä¸­é€šè¿‡ä¸æ¯ä¸ªå…ƒç´ æ¯”è¾ƒå†³å®šæ¯ä¸ªæ–‡æœ¬å…ƒç´ çš„é‡è¦ç­‰çº§ã€‚paperä¸­æå‡ºä¸€ç§lightweight convolutionä»¥åŠä¸€ç§dynamic convolutionã€‚

We predict separate convolution kernels based solely on the current time-step in order to determine the importance of context elements. The number of operations required by this approach scales linearly in the input length, whereas self-attention is quadratic.

separate convolution kernelä¸»è¦åŸºäºå½“å‰time-step,æ“ä½œæ¬¡æ•°ä¸è¾“å…¥é•¿åº¦çº¿æ€§ç›¸å…³ï¼Œè€Œä¸”self-attentionæ˜¯äºŒæ¬¡çš„ã€‚

1.Introduction

RNNs integrate context information by updating a hidden state at every time-step, CNNs summarize a fifixed size context through multiple layers, while as self-attention directly summarizes all context.

RNNé€šè¿‡åœ¨æ¯ä¸ªæ—¶é—´ç‚¹æ›´æ–°éšè—çŠ¶æ€

[^Self-attention computes attention weights by comparing all pairs of elements to each other hile as dynamic convolutions predict separate kernels for each time-step (b).]:

æœ¬æ–‡ä»‹ç»äº†lightweight convolution,å®ƒdepth-wise separable,softmax-normalized and share weight over the channel dimension.è½»é‡çº§å·ç§¯ç›¸æ¯”äºæ ‡å‡†å·ç§¯çš„æƒå€¼å°‘å‡ ä¸ªé‡çº§ï¼Œå¯¹ä¸Šä¸‹æ–‡é‡å¤ä½¿ç”¨ç›¸åŒçš„æƒå€¼å¿½ç•¥å½“å‰çš„æ—¶é—´ç‚¹ã€‚

entry.title: Multi-Scale attention-seq
entry.content:
Title

ã€ŠMUSE: PARALLEL MULTI-SCALE ATTENTION FOR SEQUENCE TO SEQUENCE LEARNINGã€‹

Abstract

Q:

attention mechanism alone suffer from dispersed weights not suit long seq

1.the attention in deep layers tends to over-concentrate on a single token

2.insufficient use of local info

3.difficult in representing long seq

S:

parallel multi-scale representation

condition:

More importantly, we find that although conceptually simple, its success in practice requires intricate considerations, and the multi-scale attention must build on unifified semantic space.

1.Introduction

Transformer mainly adept at seq tasks like MT,text classiification,language modeling.

It is solely based on an attention mechanism that captures global dependencies between input tokens, dispensing with recurrence and convolutions entirely. The key idea of the self-attention mechanism is updating token representations based on a weighted sum of all input representations.

TransformeråŸºäºä¸€ç§è‡ªæ³¨æ„åŠ›æœºåˆ¶ï¼Œè¿™ç§æœºåˆ¶å¯ä»¥é€šè¿‡é€’å½’å’Œå·ç§¯æ¥æ•æ‰è¾“å…¥ä»¤ç‰Œä¹‹é—´çš„å…¨å±€ä¾èµ–ï¼Œåœ¨æ‰€æœ‰è¾“å…¥è¡¨ç¤ºçš„æƒå€¼çš„åŸºç¡€ä¸Šæ›´æ–°ä»¤ç‰Œã€‚

å°è¯•é™åˆ¶æ³¨æ„åŠ›åªå…³æ³¨é•¿åºåˆ—çš„ä¸€éƒ¨åˆ†ï¼Œä½†æ˜¯è¿™ç§æ–¹æ³•ç”±äºé•¿è·ç¦»ä¾èµ–ä»£ä»·å¤ªé«˜ï¼Œä¹Ÿæ²¡æœ‰æ˜¾ç¤ºå‡ºseq to seqå­¦ä¹ çš„æœ‰æ•ˆæ€§ã€‚æ˜¯ä¸ºå»ºç«‹ä¸€ä¸ªå…·æœ‰å±€éƒ¨å’Œå…¨å±€ä¸Šä¸‹æ–‡å»ºæ¨¡çš„å½’çº³åå·®çš„æ¨¡å—ï¼Œå°†self-attentionä¸convolutionç»“åˆï¼Œæå‡ºmulti-scale attention called MUSE.attentionç”¨äºæ•æ‰ä¾èµ–ï¼Œconvolutionè¡¥å¿å±€éƒ¨ä¿¡æ¯çš„ä¸è¶³ï¼Œå¹¶ä¸”æœ‰æ‰©å±•æ€§ã€‚

2.MUSEï¼šParallel Multi-Scale Attention

MUSE has encoder-decoder framework,encoder has word embedding as input(x1,x2,â€¦,xn),Muse transfer X to z,ç»™å®š zï¼Œè§£ç å™¨å†ç”Ÿæˆæ–‡æœ¬åºåˆ—yã€‚encoder is a stack of N MUSE.decoderä¸encoderç›¸ä¼¼ï¼Œdecoderä¸ä»…åœ¨æ–‡æœ¬è¡¨ç¤ºä¸­æ•æ‰ç‰¹å¾ï¼Œè€Œä¸”ç”¨additional context attentionå¯¹è¾“å‡ºçš„ç¼–ç æ ˆè¿›è¡Œattentionã€‚

MUSEæœ‰ä¸‰ä¸ªä¸»è¦éƒ¨åˆ†ï¼šself-attention(global feature),depth-wise separable convolution(local),position-wise feed-forward network(token).

2.1 Attention Mechanism

ç»™å®šè¾“å…¥seq Xï¼Œè½¬æ¢æˆK,Q,Vï¼Œå†ç”¨self-attentionå¾—åˆ°è¾“å‡ºã€‚

self-attention is dot-production:

2.2Convolution

depth-wise convolution has 2 transformers:point-wise projecting,contextual transformation.

Shared projection

the shared projection project the input feature into the same hidden space.

entry.title: deep transformer-NMT
entry.content:
Title:

ã€ŠVery Deep Transformers for Neural Machine Translationã€‹

Qï¼š

how to decrease the variance of the output layer in order to train deep Trsnaformer for NMT?

S:

use a initialization named â€œADMINâ€ to remedy the variance problem and stabilize training

C:

outperform their 6-layer baseline,with up to 2.5BLEU improvement.

The code and trained models will be publicly available at: https://github.com/namisan/exdeep-nmt.

entry.title: Back-Translation
entry.content:
title:ã€ŠUnderstanding Back-Translation at Scaleã€‹

Q:

how to improve neural machine translation with monolingual data?

S:

augment the parallel training corpus with back-tranalations of targetlanguage sentences.

C:

sampling or noisy synthetic data better.

new state of the art of 35 BLEU on the WMTâ€™14 English-German test set.

Abstract

â€‹ We find that in all but resource poor settings back-translations obtained via sampling or noised beam outputs are most effective. Our analysis shows that sampling or noisy synthetic data gives a much stronger training signal than data generated by beam or greedy search.

entry.title: neo4j
entry.content:
ä¸€ã€Basic concepts

Example graphï¼š

1.Nodesï¼šrepresent entities
2.Labelsï¼šgroup nodes into sets by a certain label

[^one node can get 0 to more lables]:

3.Relationshipï¼š
connects two nodes,orgabize nodes into structure,allow a graph to resemble a list,tree,map,compound entity
4.Relationship types

a relationship must have exactly one type.And type can have value with some items

5.Properties(å±æ€§)

name-value pairs

[^eg:node Person has two properties:name and born.]:

the value part of th eproperty can hold different data types:number string,bool(refer to â€œCypel manualâ€)

6.Traversals and paths

Traversing a graph means visiting nodes by following relationships according to some rules.

The traversal result could be returned as a path with the length one:

The shorstest path has length zero.(a single node and no relationship)

7.Schemaï¼ˆindexs and constraint)

Neo4j is schema optional.

â€‹ 7.1.indexï¼ˆincrease performance)

â€‹ 7.2.constraint:Constraints are used to make sure that the data adheres to the rules of the domain.

Naming rules and recommendations

8.Cyper
9.Pattern(æ¨¡å¼ï¼šæè¿°æ‰€éœ€æ•°æ®çš„å½¢çŠ¶)

A single node or relationship typically encodes very little information, but a pattern of nodes and relationships can encode arbitrarily complex ideas.

Cypher, Neo4jâ€™s query language, is strongly based on patterns. Specifically, patterns are used to match desired graph structures. Once a matching structure has been found or created, Neo4j can use it for further processing.

[^simple patternï¼šonly a single relationship,such as:a Person LIVES_IN a City]:
[^Complex pattern: match instance where a Person LIVES_IN a Country]: (:Person) -[:LIVES_IN]-> (:City) -[:PART_OF]-> (:Country)//å›¾æ ‡å’Œç®­å¤´ç”¨æ¥å¯è§†åŒ–å›¾è¡¨

10.Node syntax

(matrix:Movie {title: â€œThe Matrixâ€, released: 1997})

()represent a node(anonymous,uncharacterrized node)

(matrix):å®šä¹‰ä¸€ç§å˜é‡ï¼Œåªåœ¨å•ä¸ªè¯­å¥ä¸­æœ‰æ„ä¹‰

:Movie is pattern

{title: â€œThe Matrixâ€, released: 1997} : properties

11.Relationship syntax
-[role:ACTED_IN {roles: ["Neo"]}]->

[^ACTED_INè¡¨ç¤ºå…³ç³»çš„ç±»å‹ï¼ˆç±»ä¼¼äºèŠ‚ç‚¹çš„æ ‡ç­¾]:

(â€“):æ— å®šå‘å…³ç³»

åœ¨ä¸€æ®µåŠ å…¥â€“>,<â€“è¡¨ç¤ºå®šå‘å…³ç³»

12.Pattern syntax
(keanu:Person:Actor {name: "Keanu Reeves"} )-[role:ACTED_IN {roles: ["Neo"] } ]->(matrix:Movie {title: "The Matrix"} )

[^[]å­˜å‚¨å…³ç³»å±æ€§ï¼Œï¼ˆï¼‰å­˜å‚¨èŠ‚ç‚¹å±æ€§]:

13.Pattern variables

To increase modularity and reduce repetition.Cypherå…è®¸å°†æ¨¡å¼åˆ†é…ç»™å˜é‡ï¼Œå…è®¸æ£€æŸ¥åŒ¹é…è·¯å¾„ç­‰å…¶ä»–è¡¨è¾¾å¼ä¸­ã€‚

acted_in = (:Person)-[:ACTED_IN]->(:Movie)

[^nodes(path),relationship(path),length(path):access details of a path]:

äºŒã€Patterns in practice

1.Creating data
CREATE (:Movie { title:"The Matrix",released:1997 })

CREATEè¯­å¥ç›´æ¥åˆ›å»ºæŒ‡å®šçš„æ¨¡å¼

if è¦è¿”å›åˆ›å»ºçš„æ•°æ®ï¼Œå®šä¹‰ä¸€ä¸ªå˜é‡

CREATE (p:Person { name:"Keanu Reeves", born:1964 })RETURN p

To create more complex structures,we can separate the elements with commas or use multiple CREATE statements

CREATE (a:Person { name:"Tom Hanks",  born:1956 })-[r:ACTED_IN { roles: ["Forrest"]}]->(m:Movie { title:"Forrest Gump",released:1994 })CREATE (d:Person { name:"Robert Zemeckis", born:1951 })-[:DIRECTED]->(m)RETURN a,d,r,m

2.Matching patterns

[^A MATCH statement will search for the patterns we specify and return one row per successful pattern match.we can start looking for all nodes with the Movie label:]: 

MATCH (m:Movie)RETURN m
MATCH (p:Person { name:"Keanu Reeves" })RETURN p
MATCH (p:Person { name:"Tom Hanks" })-[r:ACTED_IN]->(m:Movie)RETURN m.title, r.roles

[^å¯ä»¥é€šè¿‡identifer.propertyè®¿é—®å±æ€§]:

3.Attaching structures

[^To extand the graph with new info]: 

MATCH (p:Person { name:"Tom Hanks" })CREATE (m:Movie { title:"Cloud Atlas",released:2012 })CREATE (p)-[r:ACTED_IN { roles: ['Zachry']}]->(m)RETURN p,r,m
4.Completing patterns

Whenever we get data from external systems or are not sure if certain info already exists in the graph,can use MERGE in this function.

MERGE (m:Movie { title:"Cloud Atlas" })ON CREATE SET m.released = 2012RETURN m
MATCH (m:Movie { title:"Cloud Atlas" })MATCH (p:Person { name:"Tom Hanks" })MERGE (p)-[r:ACTED_IN]->(m)ON CREATE SET r.roles =['Zachry']RETURN p,r,m

[^MERGE è¿˜å¯ç¡®ä¿åˆ›å»ºä¸é‡å¤çš„å…³ç³»ï¼Œå‰ææ˜¯è¦ä¼ é€’ç»™å®ƒä¸¤ä¸ªå°†è¦è¢«è¿æ¥çš„èŠ‚ç‚¹ã€‚å¦‚æœåªä¼ é€’ä¸€ä¸ªèŠ‚ç‚¹ç»™MERGE è¯­å¥ï¼Œå°±ä¼šåœ¨è¯¥èŠ‚ç‚¹çš„ç›´æ¥é¢†å±…é¡¶ç‚¹ä¸­å¯»æ‰¾ï¼Œä¸å­˜åœ¨åˆ™ç›´æ¥åˆ›å»ºã€‚]: 

CREATE (y:Year { year:2014 })MERGE (y)<-[:IN_YEAR]-(m10:Month { month:10 })MERGE (y)<-[:IN_YEAR]-(m11:Month { month:11 })RETURN y,m10,m11

ä¸‰ã€Getting the correct results

1.Filtering results(ç­›é€‰ç»“æœ)

ç”¨WHEREå­å¥ï¼Œç”¨AND,OR,XOR and NOTæ„æˆäº†æ¡ä»¶è¯­å¥ã€‚

egï¼š

MATCH (m:Movie)WHERE m.title = "The Matrix"RETURN m

equalsï¼š

MATCH (m:Movie { title: "The Matrix" })RETURN m

WHEREè¯­å¥è¿˜å¯ä»¥ç”¨äºæ•°å€¼æ¯”è¾ƒï¼ŒåŒ¹é…æ­£åˆ™å…¬å¼ä»¥åŠæ£€æŸ¥åˆ—è¡¨ä¸­æ˜¯å¦å­˜åœ¨ç‰¹å®šå€¼ï¼Œæ­é…AND,OR,XOR,NOT

MATCH (p:Person)-[r:ACTED_IN]->(m:Movie)WHERE p.name =~ "K.+" OR m.released > 2000 OR "Neo" IN r.rolesRETURN p,r,m
MATCH (p:Person)-[:ACTED_IN]->(m)WHERE NOT (p)-[:DIRECTED]->()RETURN p,m
2.Returning results

literal value:arrays[1,2,3],map{name:â€wrhâ€,born:2000,movies:[â€œForrestâ€,â€¦]},properties of any node:n.name,length(array),toInteger(â€œ12â€), substring(â€œ2014-07-01â€,0,4) and coalesce(p.nickname,â€n/aâ€)

èµ·åˆ«åexpression AS alias

RETURNä¹‹åä½¿ç”¨DISTINCTè¿”å›å”¯ä¸€ç»“æœ

3.Aggregating information(èšåˆä¿¡æ¯)

count,sum,avg,min,maxå‡½æ•°

[^èšåˆæ—¶è¦è·³è¿‡NULLå€¼ï¼Œå¦‚æœæƒ³èšåˆå”¯ä¸€çš„DISTINCTå€¼ï¼Œå¯ä»¥ä½¿ç”¨countï¼ˆDISTINCT roleï¼‰]:

eg:the following statement finds out how often an actor and adirctoe work together

4.Ordering and pagination(æ’åºå’Œåˆ†ç±»)

Ordering is usingï¼š 

 ORDER BY expression [ASC|DESC]//ASCæ­£åºï¼ŒDESCé€†åº

if we return person.name,we can still ORDER BY person.age,because it return the person reference

Pagination is done using SKIP{offset} and LIMIT {count} clauses

For instance to find the most prolific actors we could do:

MATCH (a:Person)-[:ACTED_IN]->(m:Movie)RETURN a, count(*) AS appearancesORDER BY appearances DESC LIMIT 10;
5.Collecting aggregation

use collect() in the parent-child strutures

The following statement could be used to retrieve the cast of each movie in our database:

MATCH (m:Movie)<-[:ACTED_IN]-(a:Person)RETURN m.title AS movie, collect(a.name) AS cast, count(*) AS actors
+-----------------------------------------+| movie | cast | actors |+-----------------------------------------+| "Forrest Gump" | ["Tom Hanks"] | 1 || "Cloud Atlas" | ["Tom Hanks"] | 1 |+-----------------------------------------+2 rows
Reference

www.neo4j.com

entry.title: Wuenda's class(2)
entry.content:
p1.Train/dev/test sets

Trainï¼šè®­ç»ƒé›†ï¼Œç”¨æ¥è®­ç»ƒå„ç§æ¨¡å‹

devï¼šéªŒè¯é›†(development set)/Hold-out cross validation setï¼Œè¯„ä¼°è¿™äº›æ¨¡å‹ï¼Œé€šè¿‡è¿­ä»£é€‰å‡ºæœ€ä¼˜æ¨¡å‹

testï¼šæµ‹è¯•é›†ï¼Œéœ€è¦å¯¹æœ€ç»ˆé€‰å®šçš„ç¥ç»æ¨¡å‹è¿›è¡Œæœ€ä¼˜ä¼°è®¡ï¼ˆå¯é€‰ï¼‰

[^å°æ•°æ®é›†Train:dev:test=6:2:2 æ•°æ®é›†è¾ƒå¤§ï¼ˆegï¼š100ä¸‡dataéªŒè¯é›†å’Œæµ‹è¯•é›†å¯èƒ½åªè¾¾åˆ°0.25%ï¼‰]:

dev,testé€‰æ‹©çš„æ•°æ®æ¥æºéœ€ç›¸åŒï¼Œæ‰èƒ½æœ‰æ›´å¥½çš„æ•ˆæœ

p2Bias/Varianceåå·®/æ–¹å·®

high bias:underfitting

high variance: overfitting

[^Train set error å°ï¼Œdev set errorå¤§è¯´æ˜è¿‡æ‹Ÿåˆæ–¹å·®å¤§ ï¼›Train set error å¤§ï¼Œdev set errorå°è¯´æ˜æ¬ æ‹Ÿåˆåå·®å¤§]:

p3æœºå™¨å­¦ä¹ åŸºç¡€

P4Regulation

P5How does regularization prevent overfitting

ifæ­£åˆ™åŒ–å‚æ•°è®¾ç½®çš„è¶³å¤Ÿå¤§ï¼Œæƒé‡çŸ©é˜µè¢«è®¾ç½®ä¸ºæ¥è¿‘ä¸ºé›¶ï¼ŒåŸºæœ¬ä¸Šæ¶ˆé™¤äº†éšè—çš„å½±å“ã€‚è¿™æ ·å°±ä¼šä»è¿‡æ‹Ÿåˆçš„çŠ¶æ€æ¥è¿‘é«˜åå·®çš„çŠ¶æ€ã€‚

ä½†ä¼šå­˜åœ¨ä¸€ä¸ªä¸­é—´å€¼ï¼Œå³â€œJust Rightâ€çŠ¶æ€ã€‚æ¶ˆé™¤æˆ–å‡å°‘è®¸å¤šéšè—å•å…ƒçš„å½±å“ï¼Œç¥ç»ç½‘ç»œä¼šè¶Šæ¥è¶Šæ¥è¿‘é€»è¾‘å›å½’ï¼Œæ‰€æœ‰éšè—å•å…ƒä¾ç„¶å­˜åœ¨ï¼Œä½†æ˜¯ç¥ç»ç½‘ç»œå˜ç®€å•äº†ã€‚

å¦‚æœæ­£åˆ™åŒ–å‚æ•°å˜å¾—å¾ˆå¤§ï¼Œå‚æ•°Wå¾ˆå°ï¼Œzä¹Ÿä¼šç›¸å¯¹å˜å°ï¼Œæ­¤æ—¶å¿½ç•¥bçš„å½±å“ï¼Œzä¼šç›¸å¯¹å˜å°ï¼Œå®é™…ä¸Šï¼Œzçš„å–å€¼èŒƒå›´å¾ˆå°ï¼Œè¿™ä¸ªæ¿€æ´»å‡½æ•°ï¼Œä¹Ÿå°±æ˜¯æ›²çº¿å‡½æ•°tanhä¼šç›¸å¯¹å‘ˆçº¿æ€§ï¼Œæ•´ä¸ªç¥ç»ç½‘ç»œä¼šè®¡ç®—ç¦»çº¿æ€§å‡½æ•°è¿‘çš„å€¼ï¼Œè¿™ä¸ªçº¿æ€§å‡½æ•°éå¸¸ç®€å•ï¼Œå¹¶ä¸æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªæå¤æ‚çš„é«˜åº¦éçº¿æ€§å‡½æ•°ï¼Œä¸ä¼šå‘ç”Ÿè¿‡æ‹Ÿåˆã€‚

Dropout regularizationï¼ˆä¸»è¦åº”ç”¨åœ¨cvï¼‰

[^keep_prob:ä¿ç•™æ¯ä¸€ä¸ªèŠ‚ç‚¹çš„æ¦‚ç‡ã€‚]:

å¦‚æœæŸäº›å±‚éœ€è¦å»é™¤è¿‡æ‹Ÿåˆï¼Œé‚£ä¹ˆkeep_probå°±éœ€è¦è®¾ç½®çš„å¤§ä¸€äº›ã€‚

p9å½’ä¸€åŒ–è¾“å…¥

ä¸€ç§åŠ é€Ÿç¥ç»ç½‘ç»œè®­ç»ƒé€Ÿåº¦çš„æ–¹æ³•ã€‚

å³å›¾æ¯”å·¦å›¾çš„ä»£ä»·å‡½æ•°æ›´å®¹æ˜“æ‰¾åˆ°minå€¼ï¼Œæœ‰å›¾éœ€è¦æ¢¯åº¦ä¸‹é™è¿­ä»£å¯»æ‰¾ã€‚

p10Vanishing/exploding gradients

entry.title: Word Representation-Sememes
entry.content:
Abstract

Sememes are minimum semantic units of word meanings, and the meaning of each word sense is typically composed by several sememes.

ä¹‰åŸæ˜¯äººä¸ºæ ‡è®°çš„ï¼Œæ ‡è®°ä¹‰åŸåæœ€ç»ˆå½¢æˆè¯­ä¹‰å¸¸è¯†çŸ¥è¯†åº“ã€‚word representation learning(WRL)å°±æ˜¯æŠŠè¯è¯­æ˜ å°„åˆ°ä½ç»´ç©ºé—´ä¸­ã€‚æœ¬æ–‡æå‡ºäº†ä¸‰ç§ä¹‰åŸç¼–ç æ¨¡å‹æ¥å­¦ä¹ ä¹‰åŸã€æ„è¯†ã€è¯è¯­çš„è¡¨ç¤ºï¼Œå†ç»“åˆattentionæœºåˆ¶æ¥å‘ç°è¯è¯­æ„è¯†ã€‚

é€šè¿‡æ¯”è¾ƒåœ¨ç»™å®šçš„æ•°æ®é›†ä¸Šï¼Œé€šè¿‡è¯è¯­è¡¨ç¤ºå­¦ä¹ æ¨¡å‹è®¡ç®—å‡ºçš„è¯å¯¹ç›¸ä¼¼åº¦æ¥è¡¡é‡è¯è¯­è¡¨ç¤ºçš„è´¨é‡ã€‚è¯è¯­è¡¨ç¤ºå­¦ä¹ æ¨¡å‹åœ¨è¯­ä¹‰ç©ºé—´ä¸­ï¼Œæ ¹æ®è¯è¯­çš„è·ç¦»æ¥è®¡ç®—è¯è¯­ç›¸ä¼¼åº¦ã€‚

è¯è¯­ç±»æ¯”æ¨ç†æ˜¯ç”¨æ¥è¯„ä»·æ¨¡å‹è¯è¯­è¡¨ç¤ºå­¦ä¹ è´¨é‡çš„ä»»åŠ¡ã€‚

åˆ©ç”¨ä¹‰åŸä¿¡æ¯æ¥è¡¨ç¤ºæ¯ä¸€ä¸ªè¯å„ç§å„æ ·çš„è¯­ä¹‰ï¼Œæå‡ºäº†å¯ä»¥è‡ªåŠ¨åœ°ä¸Šä¸‹æ–‡ä¸­é€‰å–åˆé€‚çš„è¯­ä¹‰çš„ä¹‰åŸæ³¨æ„åŠ›ã€‚

# -*- coding: utf-8 -*-import numpy as np# N is batch size; D_in is input dimension;# H is hidden dimension; D_out is output dimension.N, D_in, H, D_out = 64, 1000, 100, 10# Create random input and output datax = np.random.randn(N, D_in)y = np.random.randn(N, D_out)# Randomly initialize weightsw1 = np.random.randn(D_in, H)w2 = np.random.randn(H, D_out)learning_rate = 1e-6for t in range(500):    # Forward pass: compute predicted y    h = x.dot(w1)    h_relu = np.maximum(h, 0)    y_pred = h_relu.dot(w2)    # Compute and print loss    loss = np.square(y_pred - y).sum()    print(t, loss)    # Backprop to compute gradients of w1 and w2 with respect to loss    grad_y_pred = 2.0 * (y_pred - y)    grad_w2 = h_relu.T.dot(grad_y_pred)    grad_h_relu = grad_y_pred.dot(w2.T)    grad_h = grad_h_relu.copy()    grad_h[h < 0] = 0    grad_w1 = x.T.dot(grad_h)    # Update weights    w1 -= learning_rate * grad_w1    w2 -= learning_rate * grad_w2

1.1numpy.random.randn(d0,d1,â€¦,dn)

#rand å‡½æ•°ç»™å®šç»´åº¦ç”Ÿæˆ[0,1)ä¹‹é—´çš„æ•°æ®ï¼ŒåŒ…å«0ï¼Œä¸åŒ…å«1

dnè¡¨ç¤ºæ¯ä¸ªç»´åº¦

è¿”å›å€¼ä¸ºç»´åº¦ä¸ºd0d1â€¦.*dnçš„çŸ©é˜µ

1.2range(start,stop,step)å‡½æ•°

start:è®¡æ•°å¼€å§‹ç‚¹ï¼ˆé»˜è®¤0ï¼‰

stop:æŠ€æœ¯ç»“æŸç‚¹ï¼ˆä¸åŒ…æ‹¬stopï¼‰

stepï¼šæ­¥é•¿ï¼ˆé»˜è®¤1ï¼‰

1.3numpy.dot(arr1,arr2)//numpy.dot(matrix1,matrix2)

æ±‚è§£ä¸¤æ•°ç»„çš„å†…ç§¯/çŸ©é˜µç§¯

1.4numpy.maximum(x,y)

æ±‚xä¸yè¾ƒå¤§è€…

1.5numpy.max(a,axis=None,out=None,keepdims=False)

æ±‚åºåˆ—çš„æœ€å€¼ï¼Œæœ€å°‘æ¥æ”¶ä¸€ä¸ªå‚æ•°ï¼Œaxisï¼ˆ=0ä¸ºåˆ—å‘ï¼Œ=1ä¸ºè¡Œå‘é‡ï¼‰

1.6matrix.T(m)

æ±‚çŸ©é˜µçš„è½¬ç½®

1.7numpy.square(num)

æ±‚numçš„å¹³æ–¹

2.Tensor

[^Tensoræ˜¯å¼ é‡ï¼Œå³ä»»æ„ç»´åº¦çš„å‘é‡ï¼Œpytorchå¯ä»¥åˆ©ç”¨GPUåŠ é€Ÿæ•°å­—è®¡ç®—ï¼Œè¦åœ¨GPUä¸Šè¿è¡Œpytorch Tensorï¼Œéœ€è¦å°†å…¶è½¬æ¢ä¸ºæ–°çš„æ•°æ®ç±»å‹]: 

# -*- coding: utf-8 -*-import torchdtype = torch.floatdevice = torch.device("cpu")# device = torch.device("cuda:0") # Uncomment this to run on GPU# N is batch size; D_in is input dimension;# H is hidden dimension; D_out is output dimension.N, D_in, H, D_out = 64, 1000, 100, 10# Create random input and output datax = torch.randn(N, D_in, device=device, dtype=dtype)y = torch.randn(N, D_out, device=device, dtype=dtype)# Randomly initialize weightsw1 = torch.randn(D_in, H, device=device, dtype=dtype)w2 = torch.randn(H, D_out, device=device, dtype=dtype)learning_rate = 1e-6for t in range(500):    # Forward pass: compute predicted y    h = x.mm(w1)    h_relu = h.clamp(min=0)    y_pred = h_relu.mm(w2)    # Compute and print loss    loss = (y_pred - y).pow(2).sum().item()    if t % 100 == 99:        print(t, loss)    # Backprop to compute gradients of w1 and w2 with respect to loss    grad_y_pred = 2.0 * (y_pred - y)    grad_w2 = h_relu.t().mm(grad_y_pred)    grad_h_relu = grad_y_pred.mm(w2.t())    grad_h = grad_h_relu.clone()    grad_h[h < 0] = 0    grad_w1 = x.t().mm(grad_h)    # Update weights using gradient descent    w1 -= learning_rate * grad_w1    w2 -= learning_rate * grad_w2

2.1torch.device(â€˜cpuâ€™/â€˜cudaâ€™)

å°†torch.Tensoråˆ†é…åˆ°çš„è®¾å¤‡çš„å¯¹è±¡

2.2torch.mm(input,mat2,out=None)

å¯¹çŸ©é˜µinputå’Œmat2æ‰§è¡ŒçŸ©é˜µä¹˜æ³•ï¼Œè¿”å›ç»“æœçŸ©é˜µ

2.3torch.clamp(input,min,max,out=None)->Tensor

input:è¾“å…¥å¼ é‡ï¼›minï¼šé™åˆ¶èŒƒå›´ä¸‹é™ï¼›maxï¼šä¸Šé™ï¼›outï¼šè¾“å‡ºå¼ é‡

3.Autograd

[^é’ˆå¯¹å¤§å‹ç½‘ç»œè€Œè¨€ï¼Œæ‰‹åŠ¨å®ç°å‰å‘å’Œåå‘ä¼ é€’éå¸¸éº»çƒ¦ï¼Œä½¿ç”¨autogradè‡ªåŠ¨è®¡ç®—ç¥ç»ç½‘ç»œä¸­çš„åå‘ä¼ é€’ã€‚pytorchä¸­çš„autogradè½¯ä»¶åŒ…å®Œå…¨æä¾›äº†æ­¤åŠŸèƒ½ï¼Œå‰å‘ä¼ é€’å®šä¹‰ä¸€ä¸ªè®¡ç®—å›¾ï¼›èŠ‚ç‚¹ä¸ºå¼ é‡ï¼Œè¾¹ä¸ºè¾“å…¥å¼ é‡äº§ç”Ÿè¾“å‡ºå¼ é‡çš„å‡½æ•°ï¼Œæ¥ç€å°±å¯ä»¥é€šè¿‡è¯¥å›¾è¿›è¡Œåå‘ä¼ æ’­ï¼Œå¯ä»¥è½»æ¾è®¡ç®—æ¢¯åº¦ã€‚if x:Tensor,x.requires_grad=True,x.gradæ˜¯å¦ä¸€ä¸ªTensorã€‚]:

ä¸éœ€è¦æ‰‹åŠ¨é€šè¿‡ç½‘ç»œå®ç°åå‘ä¼ é€’ï¼Œä½¿ç”¨Pytorch Tensorå’Œautogradæ¥å®ç°ä¸¤å±‚ç½‘ç»œã€‚

# -*- coding: utf-8 -*-import torchdtype = torch.floatdevice = torch.device("cpu")# device = torch.device("cuda:0") # Uncomment this to run on GPU# N is batch size; D_in is input dimension;# H is hidden dimension; D_out is output dimension.N, D_in, H, D_out = 64, 1000, 100, 10# Create random Tensors to hold input and outputs.# Setting requires_grad=False indicates that we do not need to compute gradients# with respect to these Tensors during the backward pass.x = torch.randn(N, D_in, device=device, dtype=dtype)y = torch.randn(N, D_out, device=device, dtype=dtype)# Create random Tensors for weights.# Setting requires_grad=True indicates that we want to compute gradients with# respect to these Tensors during the backward pass.w1 = torch.randn(D_in, H, device=device, dtype=dtype, requires_grad=True)w2 = torch.randn(H, D_out, device=device, dtype=dtype, requires_grad=True)learning_rate = 1e-6for t in range(500):    # Forward pass: compute predicted y using operations on Tensors; these    # are exactly the same operations we used to compute the forward pass using    # Tensors, but we do not need to keep references to intermediate values since    # we are not implementing the backward pass by hand.    y_pred = x.mm(w1).clamp(min=0).mm(w2)    # Compute and print loss using operations on Tensors.    # Now loss is a Tensor of shape (1,)    # loss.item() gets the scalar value held in the loss.    loss = (y_pred - y).pow(2).sum()    if t % 100 == 99:        print(t, loss.item())    # Use autograd to compute the backward pass. This call will compute the    # gradient of loss with respect to all Tensors with requires_grad=True.    # After this call w1.grad and w2.grad will be Tensors holding the gradient    # of the loss with respect to w1 and w2 respectively.    loss.backward()    # Manually update weights using gradient descent. Wrap in torch.no_grad()    # because weights have requires_grad=True, but we don't need to track this    # in autograd.    # An alternative way is to operate on weight.data and weight.grad.data.    # Recall that tensor.data gives a tensor that shares the storage with    # tensor, but doesn't track history.    # You can also use torch.optim.SGD to achieve this.    with torch.no_grad():        w1 -= learning_rate * w1.grad        w2 -= learning_rate * w2.grad        # Manually zero the gradients after updating weights        w1.grad.zero_()        w2.grad.zero_()

3.1

entry.title: Attention is all your need
entry.content:
Sourceï¼šhttps://arxiv.org/pdf/1706.03762.pdf

Expanding knowledge

1.RNN(Recurrent Neural Network)å¾ªç¯ç¥ç»ç½‘ç»œï¼šä¸ºäº†èƒ½æ›´å¥½çš„å¤„ç†å‰åç›¸å…³çš„sequenceä¿¡æ¯æå‡ºäº†RNNã€‚å‡è®¾è¯¥ç½‘ç»œåœ¨è¾“å…¥ä¸ºxtï¼Œéšè—å±‚ä¸ºstï¼Œè¾“å‡ºä¸ºotï¼Œå‰æä¸‹ï¼Œstçš„å€¼ä¸ä»…å–å†³äºxtï¼Œè¿˜å–å†³äºst-1

æå‡ºRNNçš„åŸå› æ˜¯CNNå’Œäººå·¥ç¿»è¯‘éƒ½å‡è®¾è¾“å…¥è¾“å‡ºçš„ç›¸äº’ç‹¬ç«‹çš„ï¼Œä½†RNNå¯ä»¥è§£å†³è¾“å…¥è¾“å‡ºä¸ç‹¬ç«‹çš„æƒ…å†µï¼Œå°†ç¥ç»ç½‘ç»œåŠ å…¥è®°å¿†ã€‚å†ä½¿ç”¨æ¿€æ´»å‡½æ•°è¿›è¡Œéçº¿æ€§æ˜ å°„è¿‡æ»¤æ— ç”¨çš„ä¿¡æ¯ï¼Œåªè®°ä½é‡è¦çš„ä¿¡æ¯ï¼Œä½¿ç”¨softmaxæ¥è¿›è¡Œé¢„æµ‹ä¸‹ä¸€ä¸ªè¯å‡ºç°çš„æ¦‚ç‡ï¼Œé¢„æµ‹æ—¶è¦å¸¦æƒé‡çŸ©é˜µã€‚

[^ä¸CNNç›¸åŒï¼ŒRNNæ¯ä¸ªcelléƒ½å…±äº«ï¼ˆU,V,W),æå¤§é™ä½è®¡ç®—é‡]:

åŒå‘RNNæ˜¯åœ¨RNNçš„åŸºç¡€ä¸Šé¢„æµ‹å½“å‰çŠ¶æ€éœ€è¦è€ƒè™‘å‰åçš„ä¿¡æ¯ã€‚

2.CNN(Conventional Neural Network)å·ç§¯ç¥ç»ç½‘ç»œ

3.LSTMé•¿çŸ­æ—¶è®°å¿†ï¼ˆLong Short Time Memory)ï¼š

1.å¤„ç†å’Œé¢„æµ‹æ—¶é—´åºåˆ—ä¸­é—´éš”å’Œå»¶è¿Ÿç›¸å¯¹è¾ƒé•¿çš„é‡è¦äº‹ä»¶ï¼ˆåœ¨è¯æ±‡é¢„æµ‹ä¸­å¦‚æœå…³è”è¯ç›¸å·®è¾ƒè¿œï¼ŒRNNå°±ä¼šå‡ºç°â€œæ¢¯åº¦æ¶ˆå¤±â€çš„é—®é¢˜

2.ä¸‰ç§é—¨ï¼šé—å¿˜é—¨ï¼ˆä¸¢å¼ƒçš„ä¿¡æ¯ï¼‰ã€è¾“å…¥é—¨ï¼ˆæ–°åŠ å…¥çš„ä¿¡æ¯ï¼‰ã€è¾“å‡ºé—¨ï¼ˆè¾“å‡ºçš„ä¿¡æ¯ï¼‰

attentionæœºåˆ¶

ä¸RNN,CNNä¸åŒï¼Œå®Œå…¨é‡‡ç”¨çš„æ˜¯attentionæœºåˆ¶ï¼Œå…·æœ‰æ›´å¼ºçš„çš„å¹¶è¡Œæ€§ã€èŠ‚çº¦äº†è®­ç»ƒçš„æ—¶é—´

Abstract

seqç¿»è¯‘æ¨¡å‹ä¸»è¦åŸºäºå¤æ‚çš„recurrent or convolution ç¥ç»ç½‘ç»œï¼Œå®ƒåŒ…æ‹¬ä¸€ä¸ªè§£ç å™¨ä¸€ä¸ªç¼–ç å™¨ï¼Œè¡¨ç°æœ€å¥½çš„æ¨¡å‹ä¹Ÿé€šè¿‡æ³¨æ„åŠ›æœºåˆ¶è¿æ¥äº†è§£ç ç¼–ç å™¨ã€‚

S:Transformerä»…ä»…åŸºäºæ³¨æ„åŠ›æœºåˆ¶ï¼Œä¸CNN,RNNå‡æ— å…³ï¼Œå‘ç°Transformerå…·æœ‰æ›´å¥½çš„å¹¶è¡Œæ€§ï¼Œä½¿ç”¨äº†æ›´å°‘çš„æ—¶é—´å»è®­ç»ƒã€‚

C:28.4BLEU on WMT2014 English-to-German translation task,æˆ‘ä»¬å‘ç°Transformerä¹Ÿå¯å¾ˆå¥½çš„æ¨å¹¿åˆ°å…¶ä»–ä»»åŠ¡ï¼Œlike English constituency parsing both with large and limited training data.

Introduction

Recurrent modelé€šå¸¸æ²¿ç€è¾“å…¥è¾“å‡ºçš„æ ‡è®°ä½ç½®è¿›è¡Œè®¡ç®—ï¼Œå°†positionä¸å½“å‰æ—¶é—´å¯¹é½ç”Ÿæˆéšè—çŠ¶æ€htï¼Œä½œä¸ºht-1çš„å‡½æ•°ä»¥åŠposition tçš„è¾“å…¥ï¼Œå¯¹äºé•¿åºåˆ—çš„å¤„ç†è‡³å…³é‡è¦ï¼Œå› ä¸ºå†…å­˜æœ‰é™åˆ¶ï¼Œæœ€è¿‘é€šè¿‡factorization tricks and conditional computationæé«˜äº†è®¡ç®—æ•ˆç‡ï¼Œåè€…æé«˜äº†æ¨¡å‹çš„è¡¨ç°ï¼Œä½†é¡ºåºè®¡ç®—çš„é™åˆ¶ä¾æ—§å­˜åœ¨ã€‚

Background

åŸºç¡€æ˜¯Extended Neural GPU,ByteNet,ConvS2S,å®ƒä»¬ä¸­ä¸¤ä¸ªè¯æ±‡ä¹‹é—´çš„ä¾èµ–å…³ç³»ä¸ä¸¤è€…ä¹‹é—´çš„è·ç¦»åç›¸å…³ï¼Œè¿™æ ·å¦‚æœä¸¤ä¸ªè¯æ±‡çš„è·ç¦»å¤ªè¿œå®ƒä»¬çš„ä¾èµ–æ€§å°±å¾ˆéš¾ä½“ç°ã€‚Transformeræ¨¡å‹é’ˆå¯¹è¿™ç§ç¼ºé™·æå‡ºäº†Multi-Head Attentionï¼ŒTransformeræ¨¡å‹æ²¡æœ‰ä½¿ç”¨RNN,CNNï¼Œå®ƒå…¨éƒ¨ä½¿ç”¨äº†attentionæœºåˆ¶å¯¹æ•´ä¸ªæœºåˆ¶è¿›è¡Œç›‘æ§ã€‚

Model Architecture

Encoder: 6 identical layers,Each layer has 2 sub-layers.One is Multi-Head Attenion,The other is a feed-forward network.Between the two sub-layers,there is a residual connection followed by layer normalization(dmodel=512).output is **
$$
LayerNorm(x+Sublater(x))
$$
**Decoder:compared with encoder,the decoder has 3 sub-layers,the 3rd layer perform multi-head attention over the output of the encoder stack.The attention ensures the prediction for position i depend only on the pre-position.

basic knowledge

  1. Embeddingï¼šå¼•ç”¨one-hotæ–¹æ³•è¯å‘é‡ä¼šå¾ˆé«˜ç»´è€Œä¸”ç¨€ç–ï¼Œä½¿ç”¨Emeddingæ›´èƒ½æ‰¾å‡ºè¯å‘é‡çš„ç›¸ä¼¼æ€§ï¼Œè¿™æ ·å°±å¯ä»¥è¿›è¡Œé™ç»´æ“ä½œã€‚è®¡ç®—åµŒå…¥çŸ©é˜µå‰é¦–å…ˆç¡®å®šæ½œåœ¨å› å­ï¼Œå°†ä¸ªåˆ«å•è¯ç”¨æ½œåœ¨å› å­ç»„æˆçš„å‘é‡è¿›è¡Œè¡¨ç¤ºï¼Œå…¶ä»–å•è¯å¯ä»¥ç”¨çŸ©é˜µä¸­å‘é‡çš„ç´¢å¼•è¡¨ç¤ºï¼Œæ¢ç´¢å…·æœ‰ç›¸ä¼¼æ€§çš„è¯è¯­ï¼Œåˆ©ç”¨é™ç»´æŠ€æœ¯å¯¹è¯è¯­è¿›è¡Œç›¸ä¼¼æ€§å¯è§†åŒ–ã€‚

  2. positional encoding

    å¯¹ä½ç½®ä¸æ•æ„Ÿçš„æ¨¡å‹ï¼ˆæ¨¡å‹çš„è¾“å‡ºä¸éšç€æ–‡æœ¬æ•°æ®é¡ºåºçš„æ”¹å˜è€Œæ”¹å˜ï¼‰åˆ†ä¸ºä¸¤ç±»ï¼ŒSinusoidal Positional Encodingï¼ˆç›¸å¯¹ï¼‰å’ŒLearned Positional Encoding.ï¼ˆç»å¯¹ï¼‰

    [^ç»å¯¹æ˜¯å¯¹ä¸åŒä½ç½®éšæœºåˆå§‹åŒ–ä¸€ä¸ªposition embedding,ç›¸å¯¹ä½ç½®å‘é‡ï¼šç”¨æ­£ä½™å¼¦å‡½æ•°åˆ†åˆ«è¡¨ç¤ºç»å¯¹ä½ç½®ï¼Œç„¶åç”¨ä¹˜ç§¯è¡¨ç¤ºç»å¯¹ä½ç½®ï¼Œcomplex embeddingä½¿ç”¨å¤æ•°åŸŸä¸Šè¿ç»­å‡½æ•°æ¥ç¼–ç è¯åœ¨ä¸åŒä½ç½®çš„è¡¨ç¤º]:

  3. ARæ¨¡å‹(Auto-regressive)and MA(Moving-average)æ¨¡å‹

    • ARè‡ªå›å½’æ¨¡å‹

    [^æœ¬èº«å‰é¢çš„æ•°æ®å½±å“åé¢çš„æ•°æ®ï¼ˆè‡ªç›¸å…³ï¼‰ï¼Œutè¡¨ç¤ºç™½å™ªå£°ï¼Œåœ¨æ—¶é—´åºåˆ—ä¸­æ•°å€¼éšæœºæ³¢åŠ¨ï¼ŒÎ¸è‡ªå›å½’ç³»æ•°]:

    • MAç§»åŠ¨å¹³å‡æ¨¡å‹

    [^å¯¹æ—¶é—´åºåˆ—çš„ç™½å™ªå£°åºåˆ—è¿›è¡ŒåŠ æƒå’Œï¼Œå¾—åˆ°ç§»åŠ¨å¹³å‡æ–¹ç¨‹]:

Attention

the output is computed as a weighted sum of th values,where the weight assigned to each value is computed by a function of query with the corrsponding key.

1 Transformer æ¨¡å‹ç›´è§‚è®¤è¯†

é¦–å…ˆæ¥è¯´ä¸€ä¸‹transformerå’ŒLSTMçš„æœ€å¤§åŒºåˆ«, å°±æ˜¯LSTMçš„è®­ç»ƒæ˜¯è¿­ä»£çš„, æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªæ¥ä¸€ä¸ªå­—çš„æ¥, å½“å‰è¿™ä¸ªå­—è¿‡å®ŒLSTMå•å…ƒ, æ‰å¯ä»¥è¿›ä¸‹ä¸€ä¸ªå­—, è€Œtransformerçš„è®­ç»ƒæ˜¯å¹¶è¡Œçš„, å°±æ˜¯æ‰€æœ‰å­—æ˜¯å…¨éƒ¨åŒæ—¶è®­ç»ƒçš„, è¿™æ ·å°±å¤§å¤§åŠ å¿«äº†è®¡ç®—æ•ˆç‡, transformerä½¿ç”¨äº†ä½ç½®åµŒå…¥ (ğ‘ğ‘œğ‘ ğ‘–ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘œğ‘›ğ‘ğ‘™ ğ‘’ğ‘›ğ‘ğ‘œğ‘‘ğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘”) æ¥ç†è§£è¯­è¨€çš„é¡ºåº, ä½¿ç”¨è‡ªæ³¨æ„åŠ›æœºåˆ¶å’Œå…¨è¿æ¥å±‚æ¥è¿›è¡Œè®¡ç®—, è¿™äº›åé¢éƒ½ä¼šè¯¦ç»†è®²è§£.

transformeræ¨¡å‹ä¸»è¦åˆ†ä¸ºä¸¤å¤§éƒ¨åˆ†, åˆ†åˆ«æ˜¯ç¼–ç å™¨å’Œè§£ç å™¨, ç¼–ç å™¨è´Ÿè´£æŠŠè‡ªç„¶è¯­è¨€åºåˆ—æ˜ å°„æˆä¸ºéšè—å±‚(ä¸‹å›¾ä¸­ç¬¬2æ­¥ç”¨ä¹å®«æ ¼æ¯”å–»çš„éƒ¨åˆ†), å«æœ‰è‡ªç„¶è¯­è¨€åºåˆ—çš„æ•°å­¦è¡¨è¾¾. ç„¶åè§£ç å™¨æŠŠéšè—å±‚å†æ˜ å°„ä¸ºè‡ªç„¶è¯­è¨€åºåˆ—, ä»è€Œä½¿æˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥è§£å†³å„ç§é—®é¢˜, å¦‚æƒ…æ„Ÿåˆ†ç±», å‘½åå®ä½“è¯†åˆ«, è¯­ä¹‰å…³ç³»æŠ½å–, æ‘˜è¦ç”Ÿæˆ, æœºå™¨ç¿»è¯‘ç­‰ç­‰, ä¸‹é¢æˆ‘ä»¬ä»¥æœºå™¨ç¿»è¯‘ä¸ºä¾‹ç®€å•è¯´ä¸€ä¸‹ä¸‹å›¾çš„æ¯ä¸€æ­¥éƒ½åšäº†ä»€ä¹ˆ:

  1. è¾“å…¥è‡ªç„¶è¯­è¨€åºåˆ—åˆ°ç¼–ç å™¨: Why do we work?(ä¸ºä»€ä¹ˆè¦å·¥ä½œ);
  2. ç¼–ç å™¨è¾“å‡ºåˆ°éšè—å±‚, å†è¾“å…¥åˆ°è§£ç å™¨;
  3. è¾“å…¥ <ğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘¡> (èµ·å§‹)ç¬¦å·åˆ°è§£ç å™¨;
  4. å¾—åˆ°ç¬¬ä¸€ä¸ªå­—â€ä¸ºâ€;
  5. å°†å¾—åˆ°çš„ç¬¬ä¸€ä¸ªå­—â€ä¸ºâ€è½ä¸‹æ¥å†è¾“å…¥åˆ°è§£ç å™¨;
  6. å¾—åˆ°ç¬¬äºŒä¸ªå­—â€ä»€â€;

entry.title: MRC for NER
entry.content:
title

A Unified MRC Framework for Named Entity Recognition

Abstract:The task of named entity recognition (NER) is normally divided into nested NER and flat NER depending on whether named entities are nested or not. Models are usually separately developed for the two tasks, since sequence labeling models are only able to assign a single label to a particular token, which is unsuitable
fornested NER where a token may be assigned several labels.

entry.title: MNER-Multimodal Entity Span Detection
entry.content:
Named-entity recognition (NER) (also known as entity identification, entity chunking and entity extraction) is a subtask of information extraction that seeks to locate and classify named entities in text into pre-defined categories such as the names of persons, organizations, locations, expressions of times, quantities, monetary values, percentages, etc.

A example of NER:

Jim bought 300 shares of Acme Corp. in 2006.
[Jim]Person bought 300 shares of [Acme Corp.]Organization in [2006]Time.

level:ACL2020

author:Jianfei Yu

keywords:MNER,Entity Span Detection

##Qusetions

MNER drawbacks

  • the words are insensitive to the visual context

    ç°æœ‰çš„æ–¹æ³•ä¾§é‡æ¨¡æ€é—´äº¤äº’è¿›è¡Œå»ºæ¨¡ï¼Œå› ä¸ºå•è¯çš„éšè—å±‚è¡¨ç¤ºä»ç„¶åŸºäºæ–‡æœ¬ä¸Šä¸‹æ–‡ï¼Œå¯¹è§†è§‰ä¸Šä¸‹æ–‡ä¸æ•æ„Ÿã€‚

    å¿½ç•¥äº†åˆå¹¶è§†è§‰ä¿¡æ¯çš„è¯¯å·®ã€‚å…³è”çš„å›¾ç‰‡ä¿¡æ¯åªåŒ…æ‹¬å¥å­ä¸­çš„ä¸€ä¸¤ä¸ªå®ä½“ï¼Œä¸æ¶‰åŠå…¶ä»–å®ä½“ï¼Œè¿™æ ·ä¼šä½¿å…¶ä»–å®ä½“æ— æ³•è¯†åˆ«ã€‚

  • most of the words ignore the bias brought by the visual context

Strategy:

1.main strategy:å¤šé€šé“äº¤äº’æ¨¡å—ï¼ˆMMIï¼‰ï¼šstandard Transformer layer+cross-model attention mechanism

2.auxiliary task:leverage purely text-based entity span detection

Consequence:

achieves the new state-of-the-artperformance on two benchmark datasets.

Notes

Overall Architecture of Our Unified Multimodal Transformer.

Transformeræ¨¡å‹

é‡‡ç”¨encoder-decoderæ¨¡å‹ã€‚ä¸Attentionç›¸ä¼¼

entry.title: Hexo Blog Introduce
entry.content:
Welcome to Hexo! This is my very first post. Check documentation for more info. If you get any problems when using Hexo, you can find the answer in troubleshooting.

Hexo Introduce

  • Hexo is a fast, simple and powerful blog framework. You write posts in Markdown (or other markup languages) and Hexo generates static files with a beautiful theme in seconds.
  • Hexo+github+gitee blog deployment tutorial
    • download Git&&Node.js
    • Github Register && GithubPage Create
    • Configure Git user&&mail
    • Install Theme && Config
    • Config Some Plugins
  • Good Github Page Recommand:
    • https://mazhuang.org/
    • http://www.liberxue.com/
    • https://rickfang666.github.io/about/
    • https://ahrilove.top/

Hexo Command

$ npm install hexo -g #å®‰è£…  $ npm update hexo -g #å‡çº§  $ hexo init #åˆå§‹åŒ–$ hexo new page "categories"  #æ–°å»ºé¡µé¢# ç®€å†™$ hexo n "æˆ‘çš„åšå®¢" == hexo new "æˆ‘çš„åšå®¢" #æ–°å»ºæ–‡ç« $ hexo p == hexo publish$ hexo g == hexo generate#ç”Ÿæˆ$ hexo s == hexo server #å¯åŠ¨æœåŠ¡é¢„è§ˆ  å¯¹è·Ÿé…ç½®æ–‡ä»¶ä¿®æ”¹éœ€è¦é‡å¯$ hexo d == hexo deploy#éƒ¨ç½²# æœåŠ¡å™¨$ hexo server #Hexo ä¼šç›‘è§†æ–‡ä»¶å˜åŠ¨å¹¶è‡ªåŠ¨æ›´æ–°ï¼Œæ‚¨æ— é¡»é‡å¯æœåŠ¡å™¨ã€‚$ hexo server -s #é™æ€æ¨¡å¼$ hexo server -p 5000 #æ›´æ”¹ç«¯å£$ hexo server -i 192.168.1.1 #è‡ªå®šä¹‰ IP$ hexo clean #æ¸…é™¤ç¼“å­˜db.json ç½‘é¡µæ­£å¸¸æƒ…å†µä¸‹å¯ä»¥å¿½ç•¥æ­¤æ¡å‘½ä»¤#éœ€è¦åˆ æ‰ç”¨å‘½ä»¤æ–°å»ºçš„æ–‡ç« æˆ–é¡µé¢æ—¶ï¼Œåªéœ€è¦è¿›å…¥ Hexo æ ¹ç›®å½•ä¸‹çš„ source æ–‡ä»¶å¤¹ï¼Œåˆ é™¤å¯¹åº”æ–‡ä»¶æˆ–æ–‡ä»¶å¤¹å³å¯$ hexo g #ç”Ÿæˆé™æ€é¡µé¢è‡³publicç›®å½•$ hexo s #å¼€å¯é¢„è§ˆè®¿é—®ç«¯å£ï¼ˆé»˜è®¤ç«¯å£4000ï¼Œ'ctrl + c'å…³é—­serverï¼‰$ hexo d #å°†.deployç›®å½•éƒ¨ç½²åˆ°GitHub#ç›‘è§†æ–‡ä»¶å˜åŠ¨hexo generate --watch #ç›‘è§†æ–‡ä»¶å˜åŠ¨
